001package squidpony.squidmath;
002
003import squidpony.squidmath.OpenSimplex2S.Grad2;
004import squidpony.squidmath.OpenSimplex2S.Grad3;
005import squidpony.squidmath.OpenSimplex2S.Grad4;
006
007/**
008 * K.jpg's OpenSimplex 2, faster variant
009 * <br>
010 * Using OpenSimplex 2 in its July 5, 2020 revision. This is the latest
011 * revision as of February 26, 2021.
012 * <ul>
013 *   <li>2D is standard simplex implemented using a lookup table.</li>
014 *   <li>3D is "Re-oriented 4-point BCC noise" which constructs a
015 *   congruent BCC lattice in a much different way than usual.</li>
016 *   <li>4D constructs the lattice as a union of five copies of its
017 *   reciprocal. It successively finds the closest point on each.</li>
018 * </ul>
019 * <br>
020 * This implements SquidLib's Noise2, Noise3, and Noise4 interfaces, allowing
021 * it to be used with the inner classes from {@link Noise} for things like layering
022 * octaves of noise with {@link Noise.Layered2D} or making ridged noise with
023 * {@link Noise.Ridged3D}. The {@link #getNoiseWithSeed(double, double, long)}
024 * methods just use the seed to offset the coordinates, splitting up the seed into
025 * 2, 3, or 4 smaller parts for 2D, 3D, and 4D respectively. This means the
026 * getNoiseWithSeed() methods need very large and different seeds for a visual
027 * difference to be apparent; just adding 1 to the seed won't help. The initial seed
028 * passed to {@link #OpenSimplex2F(long)} matters a lot; it can't be changed later.
029 * This is the faster variant of OpenSimplex 2, but it isn't much faster (if at all)
030 * than the Simplex noise in {@link FastNoise}.
031 */
032public class OpenSimplex2F implements Noise.Noise2D, Noise.Noise3D, Noise.Noise4D {
033        
034        private static final int PSIZE = 2048;
035        private static final int PMASK = 2047;
036
037        private final short[] perm;
038        private final Grad2[] permGrad2;
039        private final Grad3[] permGrad3;
040        private final Grad4[] permGrad4;
041
042        public OpenSimplex2F(){
043                this(1234567890987654321L);
044        }
045
046        public OpenSimplex2F(long seed) {
047                perm = new short[PSIZE];
048                permGrad2 = new Grad2[PSIZE];
049                permGrad3 = new Grad3[PSIZE];
050                permGrad4 = new Grad4[PSIZE];
051                short[] source = new short[PSIZE]; 
052                for (short i = 0; i < PSIZE; i++)
053                        source[i] = i;
054                for (int i = PSIZE - 1; i >= 0; i--) {
055                        seed = seed * 6364136223846793005L + 1442695040888963407L;
056                        int r = (int)((seed >>> 32) * (i + 1) >>> 32);
057                        perm[i] = source[r];
058                        permGrad2[i] = GRADIENTS_2D[perm[i]];
059                        permGrad3[i] = GRADIENTS_3D[perm[i]];
060                        permGrad4[i] = GRADIENTS_4D[perm[i]];
061                        source[r] = source[i];
062                }
063        }
064        
065        /*
066         * Noise Evaluators
067         */
068        
069        /**
070         * 2D Simplex noise, standard lattice orientation.
071         */
072        public double noise2(double x, double y) {
073                
074                // Get points for A2* lattice
075                double s = 0.366025403784439 * (x + y);
076                double xs = x + s, ys = y + s;
077                
078                return noise2_Base(xs, ys);
079        }
080        
081        /**
082         * 2D Simplex noise, with Y pointing down the main diagonal.
083         * Might be better for a 2D sandbox style game, where Y is vertical.
084         * Probably slightly less optimal for heightmaps or continent maps.
085         */
086        public double noise2_XBeforeY(double x, double y) {
087                
088                // Skew transform and rotation baked into one.
089                double xx = x * 0.7071067811865476;
090                double yy = y * 1.224744871380249;
091                
092                return noise2_Base(yy + xx, yy - xx);
093        }
094        
095        /**
096         * 2D Simplex noise base.
097         * Lookup table implementation inspired by DigitalShadow.
098         */
099        private double noise2_Base(double xs, double ys) {
100                double value = 0;
101                
102                // Get base points and offsets
103                long xsb = Noise.longFloor(xs), ysb = Noise.longFloor(ys);
104                double xsi = xs - xsb, ysi = ys - ysb;
105                
106                // Index to point list
107                int index = (int)((ysi - xsi) / 2 + 1);
108                
109                double ssi = (xsi + ysi) * -0.211324865405187;
110                double xi = xsi + ssi, yi = ysi + ssi;
111
112                // Point contributions
113                for (int i = 0; i < 3; i++) {
114                        LatticePoint2D c = LOOKUP_2D[index + i];
115
116                        double dx = xi + c.dx, dy = yi + c.dy;
117                        double attn = 0.5 - dx * dx - dy * dy;
118                        if (attn <= 0) continue;
119
120                        int pxm = ((int) xsb + c.xsv) & PMASK, pym = ((int) ysb + c.ysv) & PMASK;
121                        Grad2 grad = permGrad2[perm[pxm] ^ pym];
122                        double extrapolation = grad.dx * dx + grad.dy * dy;
123                        
124                        attn *= attn;
125                        value += attn * attn * extrapolation;
126                }
127                
128                return value;
129        }
130        
131        /**
132         * 3D Re-oriented 4-point BCC noise, classic orientation.
133         * Proper substitute for 3D Simplex in light of Forbidden Formulae.
134         * Use noise3_XYBeforeZ or noise3_XZBeforeY instead, wherever appropriate.
135         */
136        public double noise3_Classic(double x, double y, double z) {
137                
138                // Re-orient the cubic lattices via rotation, to produce the expected look on cardinal planar slices.
139                // If texturing objects that don't tend to have cardinal plane faces, you could even remove this.
140                // Orthonormal rotation. Not a skew transform.
141                double r = (2.0 / 3.0) * (x + y + z);
142                double xr = r - x, yr = r - y, zr = r - z;
143                
144                // Evaluate both lattices to form a BCC lattice.
145                return noise3_BCC(xr, yr, zr);
146        }
147        
148        /**
149         * 3D Re-oriented 4-point BCC noise, with better visual isotropy in (X, Y).
150         * Recommended for 3D terrain and time-varied animations.
151         * The Z coordinate should always be the "different" coordinate in your use case.
152         * If Y is vertical in world coordinates, call noise3_XYBeforeZ(x, z, Y) or use noise3_XZBeforeY.
153         * If Z is vertical in world coordinates, call noise3_XYBeforeZ(x, y, Z).
154         * For a time varied animation, call noise3_XYBeforeZ(x, y, T).
155         */
156        public double noise3_XYBeforeZ(double x, double y, double z) {
157                
158                // Re-orient the cubic lattices without skewing, to make X and Y triangular like 2D.
159                // Orthonormal rotation. Not a skew transform.
160                double xy = x + y;
161                double s2 = xy * -0.211324865405187;
162                double zz = z * 0.577350269189626;
163                double xr = x + s2 - zz, yr = y + s2 - zz;
164                double zr = xy * 0.577350269189626 + zz;
165                
166                // Evaluate both lattices to form a BCC lattice.
167                return noise3_BCC(xr, yr, zr);
168        }
169        
170        /**
171         * 3D Re-oriented 4-point BCC noise, with better visual isotropy in (X, Z).
172         * Recommended for 3D terrain and time-varied animations.
173         * The Y coordinate should always be the "different" coordinate in your use case.
174         * If Y is vertical in world coordinates, call noise3_XZBeforeY(x, Y, z).
175         * If Z is vertical in world coordinates, call noise3_XZBeforeY(x, Z, y) or use noise3_XYBeforeZ.
176         * For a time varied animation, call noise3_XZBeforeY(x, T, y) or use noise3_XYBeforeZ.
177         */
178        public double noise3_XZBeforeY(double x, double y, double z) {
179                
180                // Re-orient the cubic lattices without skewing, to make X and Z triangular like 2D.
181                // Orthonormal rotation. Not a skew transform.
182                double xz = x + z;
183                double s2 = xz * -0.211324865405187;
184                double yy = y * 0.577350269189626;
185                double xr = x + s2 - yy; double zr = z + s2 - yy;
186                double yr = xz * 0.577350269189626 + yy;
187                
188                // Evaluate both lattices to form a BCC lattice.
189                return noise3_BCC(xr, yr, zr);
190        }
191        
192        /**
193         * Generate overlapping cubic lattices for 3D Re-oriented BCC noise.
194         * Lookup table implementation inspired by DigitalShadow.
195         * It was actually faster to narrow down the points in the loop itself,
196         * than to build up the index with enough info to isolate 4 points.
197         */
198        private double noise3_BCC(double xr, double yr, double zr) {
199                
200                // Get base and offsets inside cube of first lattice.
201                long xrb = Noise.longFloor(xr), yrb = Noise.longFloor(yr), zrb = Noise.longFloor(zr);
202                double xri = xr - xrb, yri = yr - yrb, zri = zr - zrb;
203                
204                // Identify which octant of the cube we're in. This determines which cell
205                // in the other cubic lattice we're in, and also narrows down one point on each.
206                int xht = (int)(xri + 0.5), yht = (int)(yri + 0.5), zht = (int)(zri + 0.5);
207                int index = (xht << 0) | (yht << 1) | (zht << 2);
208                
209                // Point contributions
210                double value = 0;
211                LatticePoint3D c = LOOKUP_3D[index];
212                while (c != null) {
213                        double dxr = xri + c.dxr, dyr = yri + c.dyr, dzr = zri + c.dzr;
214                        double attn = 0.5 - dxr * dxr - dyr * dyr - dzr * dzr;
215                        if (attn < 0) {
216                                c = c.nextOnFailure;
217                        } else {
218                                int pxm = ((int) xrb + c.xrv) & PMASK, pym = ((int) yrb + c.yrv) & PMASK, pzm = ((int) zrb + c.zrv) & PMASK;
219                                Grad3 grad = permGrad3[perm[perm[pxm] ^ pym] ^ pzm];
220                                double extrapolation = grad.dx * dxr + grad.dy * dyr + grad.dz * dzr;
221                                
222                                attn *= attn;
223                                value += attn * attn * extrapolation;
224                                c = c.nextOnSuccess;
225                        }
226                }
227                return value;
228        }
229        
230        /**
231         * 4D OpenSimplex2F noise, classic lattice orientation.
232         */
233        public double noise4_Classic(double x, double y, double z, double w) {
234                
235                // Get points for A4 lattice
236                double s = -0.138196601125011 * (x + y + z + w);
237                double xs = x + s, ys = y + s, zs = z + s, ws = w + s;
238                
239                return noise4_Base(xs, ys, zs, ws);
240        }
241        
242        /**
243         * 4D OpenSimplex2F noise, with XY and ZW forming orthogonal triangular-based planes.
244         * Recommended for 3D terrain, where X and Y (or Z and W) are horizontal.
245         * Recommended for noise(x, y, sin(time), cos(time)) trick.
246         */
247        public double noise4_XYBeforeZW(double x, double y, double z, double w) {
248                
249                double s2 = (x + y) * -0.178275657951399372 + (z + w) * 0.215623393288842828;
250                double t2 = (z + w) * -0.403949762580207112 + (x + y) * -0.375199083010075342;
251                double xs = x + s2, ys = y + s2, zs = z + t2, ws = w + t2;
252                
253                return noise4_Base(xs, ys, zs, ws);
254        }
255        
256        /**
257         * 4D OpenSimplex2F noise, with XZ and YW forming orthogonal triangular-based planes.
258         * Recommended for 3D terrain, where X and Z (or Y and W) are horizontal.
259         */
260        public double noise4_XZBeforeYW(double x, double y, double z, double w) {
261                
262                double s2 = (x + z) * -0.178275657951399372 + (y + w) * 0.215623393288842828;
263                double t2 = (y + w) * -0.403949762580207112 + (x + z) * -0.375199083010075342;
264                double xs = x + s2, ys = y + t2, zs = z + s2, ws = w + t2;
265                
266                return noise4_Base(xs, ys, zs, ws);
267        }
268        
269        /**
270         * 4D OpenSimplex2F noise, with XYZ oriented like noise3_Classic,
271         * and W for an extra degree of freedom. W repeats eventually.
272         * Recommended for time-varied animations which texture a 3D object (W=time)
273         */
274        public double noise4_XYZBeforeW(double x, double y, double z, double w) {
275                
276                double xyz = x + y + z;
277                double ww = w * 0.2236067977499788;
278                double s2 = xyz * -0.16666666666666666 + ww;
279                double xs = x + s2, ys = y + s2, zs = z + s2, ws = -0.5 * xyz + ww;
280                
281                return noise4_Base(xs, ys, zs, ws);
282        }
283        
284        /**
285         * 4D OpenSimplex2F noise base.
286         * Current implementation not fully optimized by lookup tables.
287         * But still comes out slightly ahead of Gustavson's Simplex in tests.
288         */
289        private double noise4_Base(double xs, double ys, double zs, double ws) {
290                double value = 0;
291                
292                // Get base points and offsets
293                long xsb = Noise.longFloor(xs), ysb = Noise.longFloor(ys), zsb = Noise.longFloor(zs), wsb = Noise.longFloor(ws);
294                double xsi = xs - xsb, ysi = ys - ysb, zsi = zs - zsb, wsi = ws - wsb;
295                
296                // If we're in the lower half, flip so we can repeat the code for the upper half. We'll flip back later.
297                double siSum = xsi + ysi + zsi + wsi;
298                double ssi = siSum * 0.309016994374947; // Prep for vertex contributions.
299                boolean inLowerHalf = (siSum < 2);
300                if (inLowerHalf) {
301                        xsi = 1 - xsi; ysi = 1 - ysi; zsi = 1 - zsi; wsi = 1 - wsi;
302                        siSum = 4 - siSum;
303                }
304                
305                // Consider opposing vertex pairs of the octahedron formed by the central cross-section of the stretched tesseract
306                double aabb = xsi + ysi - zsi - wsi, abab = xsi - ysi + zsi - wsi, abba = xsi - ysi - zsi + wsi;
307                double aabbScore = Math.abs(aabb), ababScore = Math.abs(abab), abbaScore = Math.abs(abba);
308                
309                // Find the closest point on the stretched tesseract as if it were the upper half
310                int vertexIndex, via, vib;
311                double asi, bsi;
312                if (aabbScore > ababScore && aabbScore > abbaScore) {
313                        if (aabb > 0) {
314                                asi = zsi; bsi = wsi; vertexIndex = 0b0011; via = 0b0111; vib = 0b1011;
315                        } else {
316                                asi = xsi; bsi = ysi; vertexIndex = 0b1100; via = 0b1101; vib = 0b1110;
317                        }
318                } else if (ababScore > abbaScore) {
319                        if (abab > 0) {
320                                asi = ysi; bsi = wsi; vertexIndex = 0b0101; via = 0b0111; vib = 0b1101;
321                        } else {
322                                asi = xsi; bsi = zsi; vertexIndex = 0b1010; via = 0b1011; vib = 0b1110;
323                        }
324                } else {
325                        if (abba > 0) {
326                                asi = ysi; bsi = zsi; vertexIndex = 0b1001; via = 0b1011; vib = 0b1101;
327                        } else {
328                                asi = xsi; bsi = wsi; vertexIndex = 0b0110; via = 0b0111; vib = 0b1110;
329                        }
330                }
331                if (bsi > asi) {
332                        via = vib;
333                        double temp = bsi;
334                        bsi = asi;
335                        asi = temp;
336                }
337                if (siSum + asi > 3) {
338                        vertexIndex = via;
339                        if (siSum + bsi > 4) {
340                                vertexIndex = 0b1111;
341                        }
342                }
343                
344                // Now flip back if we're actually in the lower half.
345                if (inLowerHalf) {
346                        xsi = 1 - xsi; ysi = 1 - ysi; zsi = 1 - zsi; wsi = 1 - wsi;
347                        vertexIndex ^= 0b1111;
348                }
349                
350                // Five points to add, total, from five copies of the A4 lattice.
351                for (int i = 0; i < 5; i++) {
352                
353                        // Update xsb/etc. and add the lattice point's contribution.
354                        LatticePoint4D c = VERTICES_4D[vertexIndex];
355                        xsb += c.xsv; ysb += c.ysv; zsb += c.zsv; wsb += c.wsv;
356                        double xi = xsi + ssi, yi = ysi + ssi, zi = zsi + ssi, wi = wsi + ssi;
357                        double dx = xi + c.dx, dy = yi + c.dy, dz = zi + c.dz, dw = wi + c.dw;
358                        double attn = 0.5 - dx * dx - dy * dy - dz * dz - dw * dw;
359                        if (attn > 0) {
360                                int pxm = (int) xsb & PMASK, pym = (int) ysb & PMASK, pzm = (int) zsb & PMASK, pwm = (int) wsb & PMASK;
361                                Grad4 grad = permGrad4[perm[perm[perm[pxm] ^ pym] ^ pzm] ^ pwm];
362                                double ramped = grad.dx * dx + grad.dy * dy + grad.dz * dz + grad.dw * dw;
363                                
364                                attn *= attn;
365                                value += attn * attn * ramped;
366                        }
367                        
368                        // Maybe this helps the compiler/JVM/LLVM/etc. know we can end the loop here. Maybe not.
369                        if (i == 4) break;
370                        
371                        // Update the relative skewed coordinates to reference the vertex we just added.
372                        // Rather, reference its counterpart on the lattice copy that is shifted down by
373                        // the vector <-0.2, -0.2, -0.2, -0.2>
374                        xsi += c.xsi; ysi += c.ysi; zsi += c.zsi; wsi += c.wsi;
375                        ssi += c.ssiDelta;
376                        
377                        // Next point is the closest vertex on the 4-simplex whose base vertex is the aforementioned vertex.
378                        double score0 = 1.0 + ssi * (-1.0 / 0.309016994374947); // Seems slightly faster than 1.0-xsi-ysi-zsi-wsi
379                        vertexIndex = 0b0000;
380                        if (xsi >= ysi && xsi >= zsi && xsi >= wsi && xsi >= score0) {
381                                vertexIndex = 0b0001;
382                        }
383                        else if (ysi > xsi && ysi >= zsi && ysi >= wsi && ysi >= score0) {
384                                vertexIndex = 0b0010;
385                        }
386                        else if (zsi > xsi && zsi > ysi && zsi >= wsi && zsi >= score0) {
387                                vertexIndex = 0b0100;
388                        }
389                        else if (wsi > xsi && wsi > ysi && wsi > zsi && wsi >= score0) {
390                                vertexIndex = 0b1000;
391                        }
392                }
393                
394                return value;
395        }
396        
397        /*
398         * Utility
399         */
400        
401        private static int fastFloor(double x) {
402                int xi = (int)x;
403                return x < xi ? xi - 1 : xi;
404        }
405        
406        /*
407         * Definitions
408         */
409
410        private static final LatticePoint2D[] LOOKUP_2D;
411        private static final LatticePoint3D[] LOOKUP_3D;
412        private static final LatticePoint4D[] VERTICES_4D;
413        static {
414                LOOKUP_2D = new LatticePoint2D[4];
415                LOOKUP_3D = new LatticePoint3D[8];
416                VERTICES_4D = new LatticePoint4D[16];
417                
418                LOOKUP_2D[0] = new LatticePoint2D(1, 0);
419                LOOKUP_2D[1] = new LatticePoint2D(0, 0);
420                LOOKUP_2D[2] = new LatticePoint2D(1, 1);
421                LOOKUP_2D[3] = new LatticePoint2D(0, 1);
422                
423                for (int i = 0; i < 8; i++) {
424                        int i1, j1, k1, i2, j2, k2;
425                        i1 = (i >> 0) & 1; j1 = (i >> 1) & 1; k1 = (i >> 2) & 1;
426                        i2 = i1 ^ 1; j2 = j1 ^ 1; k2 = k1 ^ 1;
427                        
428                        // The two points within this octant, one from each of the two cubic half-lattices.
429                        LatticePoint3D c0 = new LatticePoint3D(i1, j1, k1, 0);
430                        LatticePoint3D c1 = new LatticePoint3D(i1 + i2, j1 + j2, k1 + k2, 1);
431                        
432                        // Each single step away on the first half-lattice.
433                        LatticePoint3D c2 = new LatticePoint3D(i1 ^ 1, j1, k1, 0);
434                        LatticePoint3D c3 = new LatticePoint3D(i1, j1 ^ 1, k1, 0);
435                        LatticePoint3D c4 = new LatticePoint3D(i1, j1, k1 ^ 1, 0);
436                        
437                        // Each single step away on the second half-lattice.
438                        LatticePoint3D c5 = new LatticePoint3D(i1 + (i2 ^ 1), j1 + j2, k1 + k2, 1);
439                        LatticePoint3D c6 = new LatticePoint3D(i1 + i2, j1 + (j2 ^ 1), k1 + k2, 1);
440                        LatticePoint3D c7 = new LatticePoint3D(i1 + i2, j1 + j2, k1 + (k2 ^ 1), 1);
441                        
442                        // First two are guaranteed.
443                        c0.nextOnFailure = c0.nextOnSuccess = c1;
444                        c1.nextOnFailure = c1.nextOnSuccess = c2;
445                        
446                        // Once we find one on the first half-lattice, the rest are out.
447                        // In addition, knowing c2 rules out c5.
448                        c2.nextOnFailure = c3; c2.nextOnSuccess = c6;
449                        c3.nextOnFailure = c4; c3.nextOnSuccess = c5;
450                        c4.nextOnFailure = c4.nextOnSuccess = c5;
451                        
452                        // Once we find one on the second half-lattice, the rest are out.
453                        c5.nextOnFailure = c6; c5.nextOnSuccess = null;
454                        c6.nextOnFailure = c7; c6.nextOnSuccess = null;
455                        c7.nextOnFailure = c7.nextOnSuccess = null;
456                        
457                        LOOKUP_3D[i] = c0;
458                }
459                
460                for (int i = 0; i < 16; i++) {
461                        VERTICES_4D[i] = new LatticePoint4D((i >> 0) & 1, (i >> 1) & 1, (i >> 2) & 1, (i >> 3) & 1);
462                }
463        }
464
465        @Override
466        public double getNoise(double x, double y) {
467                return noise2(x, y);
468        }
469
470        @Override
471        public double getNoiseWithSeed(double x, double y, long seed) {
472                return noise2(x + (seed & 0xFFFFFFFFL), y + (seed >>> 32));
473        }
474
475        @Override
476        public double getNoise(double x, double y, double z) {
477                return noise3_Classic(x, y, z);
478        }
479
480        @Override
481        public double getNoiseWithSeed(double x, double y, double z, long seed) {
482                return noise3_Classic(x + (seed & 0x1FFFFFL), y + (seed >>> 21 & 0x1FFFFFL), z + (seed >>> 42));
483        }
484
485        @Override
486        public double getNoise(double x, double y, double z, double w) {
487                return noise4_Classic(x, y, z, w);
488        }
489
490        @Override
491        public double getNoiseWithSeed(double x, double y, double z, double w, long seed) {
492                return noise4_Classic(x + (seed & 0xFFFFL), y + (seed >>> 16 & 0xFFFFL), z + (seed >>> 32 & 0xFFFFL), w + (seed >>> 48));
493        }
494
495        private static class LatticePoint2D {
496                int xsv, ysv;
497                double dx, dy;
498                public LatticePoint2D(int xsv, int ysv) {
499                        this.xsv = xsv; this.ysv = ysv;
500                        double ssv = (xsv + ysv) * -0.211324865405187;
501                        this.dx = -xsv - ssv;
502                        this.dy = -ysv - ssv;
503                }
504        }
505        
506        private static class LatticePoint3D {
507                public double dxr, dyr, dzr;
508                public int xrv, yrv, zrv;
509                LatticePoint3D nextOnFailure, nextOnSuccess;
510                public LatticePoint3D(int xrv, int yrv, int zrv, int lattice) {
511                        this.dxr = -xrv + lattice * 0.5; this.dyr = -yrv + lattice * 0.5; this.dzr = -zrv + lattice * 0.5;
512                        this.xrv = xrv + lattice * 1024; this.yrv = yrv + lattice * 1024; this.zrv = zrv + lattice * 1024;
513                }
514        }
515        
516        private static class LatticePoint4D {
517                int xsv, ysv, zsv, wsv;
518                double dx, dy, dz, dw;
519                double xsi, ysi, zsi, wsi;
520                double ssiDelta;
521                public LatticePoint4D(int xsv, int ysv, int zsv, int wsv) {
522                        this.xsv = xsv + 409; this.ysv = ysv + 409; this.zsv = zsv + 409; this.wsv = wsv + 409;
523                        double ssv = (xsv + ysv + zsv + wsv) * 0.309016994374947;
524                        this.dx = -xsv - ssv;
525                        this.dy = -ysv - ssv;
526                        this.dz = -zsv - ssv;
527                        this.dw = -wsv - ssv;
528                        this.xsi = xsi = 0.2 - xsv;
529                        this.ysi = ysi = 0.2 - ysv;
530                        this.zsi = zsi = 0.2 - zsv;
531                        this.wsi = wsi = 0.2 - wsv;
532                        this.ssiDelta = (0.8 - xsv - ysv - zsv - wsv) * 0.309016994374947;
533                }
534        }
535
